articles.headline: Bosnian Serb Under Arrest in War Crimes
articles.snippet: The arrest of Radovan Karadzic, one of the most wanted war criminals for the massacre of nearly 8,000 Muslim men and boys, ended a 13-year hunt.
articles.abstract: The arrest of Radovan Karadzic, one of the most wanted war criminals for the massacre of nearly 8,000 Muslim men and boys, ended a 13-year hunt.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Radovan Karadzic, one of the world’s most wanted war criminals for his part in the massacre of nearly 8,000 Muslim men and boys in Srebrenica in 1995, was arrested Monday in a raid in Serbia that ended a 13-year hunt.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Marlise Simons

articles.headline: A Product’s Place Is on the Set
articles.snippet: Name-brand products make regular appearances on television shows, where they are typically written into a drama. But TV News? You bet.
articles.abstract: Name-brand products make regular appearances on television shows, where they are typically written into a drama. But TV News? You bet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Name-brand products make regular appearances on television shows, where they are typically written into a drama, comedy or reality program. “American Idol” viewers, for example, have come to expect to see a Coke cup in front of Simon Cowell as he dresses down contestants.

articles.headline: Indecency Penalty Against CBS Is Rejected
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court overturned a decision to fine CBS stations $550,000 for broadcasting a brief breast flash by Janet Jackson during the 2004 Super Bowl broadcast.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court overturned a decision to fine CBS stations $550,000 for broadcasting a brief breast flash by Janet Jackson during the 2004 Super Bowl broadcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court threw out on Monday a $550,000 fine that the Federal Communications Commission imposed on CBS for a “wardrobe malfunction” at its 2004 Super Bowl halftime show that briefly exposed the singer Janet Jackson’s breast.

articles.headline: Trial Intensifies Concerns About Safety of Vytorin
articles.snippet: The cholesterol-lowering drug Vytorin did not help people with heart-valve disease avoid further heart problems but did appear to increase their risk of cancer, scientists reported Monday.
articles.abstract: The cholesterol-lowering drug Vytorin did not help people with heart-valve disease avoid further heart problems but did appear to increase their risk of cancer, scientists reported Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a clinical trial, the cholesterol-lowering drug Vytorin did not help people with heart-valve disease avoid further heart problems but did appear to increase their risk of cancer, scientists reported Monday.

articles.headline: Ford to Make Broader Bet on Small Cars
articles.snippet: After two decades focused on trucks, the company is about to drastically shift focus to building smaller cars.
articles.abstract: After two decades focused on trucks, the company is about to drastically shift focus to building smaller cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company, which devoted itself for nearly 20 years to putting millions of Americans into big pickup trucks and sport-utility vehicles, is about to drastically alter its focus to building more small cars.

articles.headline: For Obama, a First Step Is Not a Misstep
articles.snippet: After meeting Iraqi leaders and American officials, Senator Barack Obama seemed to have navigated the riskiest part of an international trip.
articles.abstract: After meeting Iraqi leaders and American officials, Senator Barack Obama seemed to have navigated the riskiest part of an international trip.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government on Monday left little doubt that it favors a withdrawal plan for American combat troops similar to what Senator Barack Obama has proposed, providing Mr. Obama with a potentially powerful political boost on a day he spent in Iraq working to fortify his credibility as a wartime leader.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: TiVo and Amazon Team Up
articles.snippet: The two companies want to turn the television remote control into a tool for buying the products being advertised and promoted on commercials and talk shows.
articles.abstract: The two companies want to turn the television remote control into a tool for buying the products being advertised and promoted on commercials and talk shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  TiVo, the Silicon Valley company that introduced millions to the joy of skipping television commercials, is trying to crack a decades-old media dream. It wants to turn the television remote control into a tool for buying the products being advertised and promoted on commercials and talk shows.

articles.headline: As Loan Giants Are Inspected, Bush Prods Congress
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that examiners are inspecting the books of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that examiners are inspecting the books of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank examiners from the Federal Reserve and the Comptroller of the Currency are inspecting the books of the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as the Bush administration prods Congress to approve a plan that would enable it to inject billions of dollars into the companies.

articles.headline: Yahoo Deal Wards Off Proxy Fight
articles.snippet: Yahoo’s board and management earned a reprieve after a weekend deal ended a bruising and acrimonious fight for control of the company with Carl C. Icahn.
articles.abstract: Yahoo’s board and management earned a reprieve after a weekend deal ended a bruising and acrimonious fight for control of the company with Carl C. Icahn.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo’s board and management earned a reprieve after a weekend deal ended a bruising and acrimonious fight for control of the company with Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor.

articles.headline: Women Are Now Equal as Victims of Poor Economy
articles.snippet: Women in the workplace are being afflicted by the same troubles as men. And they are responding as men have, by dropping out or disappearing for a while.
articles.abstract: Women in the workplace are being afflicted by the same troubles as men. And they are responding as men have, by dropping out or disappearing for a while.
articles.lead_paragraph: Across the country, women in their prime earning years, struggling with an unfriendly economy, are retreating from the work force, either permanently or for long stretches.
